awd_titl_txt: Seventh Arab-American Frontiers of Science, Engineering, and Medicine Symposium: A Unique Opportunity for U.S.-Arab Scientific Exchange and Collaboration
awd_abstract_narration:
Many Arab countries are making significant investments in science and technology and have unique facilities and resources. However, there are few mechanisms for U.S. researchers to learn about research efforts in this region. This meeting provides an exceptional opportunity for U.S. scientists to interact with promising young researchers in the Middle East to develop new ideas and approaches to apply to ongoing research and discover opportunities for collaboration. 

This project will help support the seventh conference of the Arab-American Frontiers program series, to be held in Alexandria, Egypt in fall 2019. The event will provide an opportunity for approximately 40 early-career US scientists to attend a three-day conference of approximately 100 total attendees that seeks to: enhance scientific dialogue and exchange between young US and Arab researchers; encourage the transfer of techniques and approaches across disciplines, strengthen science and engineering collaboration within and beyond the US and the Middle East/North Africa region, and also empower young scientists, engineers and medical professionals to assume leadership roles in their fields and beyond. Participants are selected through a competitive application process, ensuring a meeting of research-active scientists and engineers who are ready to capitalize on the ideas and relationships developed at the conference. The event is co-organized by the Library of Alexandria and the Egyptian Academy of Scientific Research and Technology, and NSF funds leverage their significant support.  

The conference purposely focuses on several topics that are not directly related to encourage the participants to make connections beyond their field of study and to facilitate interdisciplinary dialogue that may offer new, unexpected insights. Participants at previous workshops have highlighted this broad interdisciplinarity as an intellectual highlight of the meeting. The focus areas for this meeting were developed by the volunteer organizing committee and represent globally important topics in which the Middle East has valuable expertise and is investing important resources. All five topics represent research challenges that require the insights of multiple disciplines.
- Sensing Technology 
- Artificial intelligence 
- Water 
- Infectious Diseases 
- Community Resilience

Further development of ideas for cooperative work that develop at the conference will be facilitated by small collaboration grants for which participants may apply after the meeting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit


The Seventh Frontiers symposium has been an unprecedented opportunity for U.S. and Arab scientists to share state of the art knowledge under the topics of artificial intelligence, sensing technologies, infectious diseases, water, and community resilience, and explore how these findings apply to the regional context. The session presentations, discussion panels, and daily poster sessions generated new ideas for cross disciplinary innovation that do not usually take place in regular, single discipline-focused conferences. The 2019 post-symposium survey indicated that 72% learned about new developments in their field while 96.6% learned about developments outside of their field. In addition, 88% identified potential applications of new approaches, tools, and/or analysis methods that can benefit their research. The same survey showed that 46% of the attendees had expertise in sensing technologies, 36.5% in water, 33% in artificial intelligence, 30.2% in infectious diseases and 25.4% in community resilience. This demonstrates that the discipline breakdown among participants was balanced, with many of them conducting transdisciplinary research.


The session on infectious diseases covered interesting research and discussion on the latest advances in detection and mitigation of infectious diseases in the U.S. and the Middle East only a couple of months prior to the onset of the CoVID-19 pandemic, therefore cementing collaborations between US and Arab researchers which continue to be leveraged to this day.
Once travel resumed in 2022, and after sustaining the program virtually through 2021, the Arab-American Frontiers program awarded fellowships to 12 participants, including two U.S. researchers who were supported through the NSF Award. In April, Dr. Luyi Sun, University of Connecticut visited researchers in both the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and Qatar to explore and establish research collaborations between his institution and Khalifa University in the UAE, and HBKU in Qatar. At Khalifa, He explored functional materials for various applications including energy, environmental, and health care with Dr. Tiejun Zhang, who is an expert on engineering and simulation, and has a well-established lab of additive manufacturing. Following discussions on 3D printing, the two researchers plan to exchange students and postdocs to better establish linkages between their respective labs.


The second fellowship supported Dr. Hiba Baroud of Vanderbilt University to visit Mrs. Maysoon Zoubi (FAO), and Dr. Abeer Balawneh, and Dr. Nizar Haddad (National Agricultural Research Center) in Jordan. While there, she worked with three research groups at NARC on agriculture risk modeling, flood adaptation, and validation of remote sensing vegetation indices; delivered a research seminar at Princess Sumaya University of Technology (PSUT) and another at NARC; participated in a workshop on youth empowerment for climate change; participated in the 5th conference of Women On the Front Lines - MENA chapter; met with the representative of the FAO in Jordan, Mr. Nabil Assaf; and met with the minister of agriculture, Dr. Nasr Edin Obaid.

 

Broader Impacts


Providing a platform for inter-disciplinary collaboration is one of the unique aspects of all existing Frontiers programs at NAS, including the Arab-American Frontiers of Science, Engineering and Medicine program. The session panels and daily poster sessions generated new ideas for cross disciplinary innovation that do not usually take place in regular single discipline-focused conferences. Speakers were selected based on their strong communication skills and were given clear instructions to prepare presentations that not only focus on the novelty of their research but also set the broader context for their field and how it can bridge out to other disciplines. As stated by a US participant in the 2019 post-meeting survey: ?This is not to be missed if you are at all interested in doing collaborative and interdisciplinary research. The way the program is designed is extremely efficient in getting people to talk to each other. The sessions and speakers were carefully picked which led to thought-provoking discussions during the panels.?


Furthermore, in an overarching survey that covered all previous symposia, attendees indicated that new connections and introductions to MENA researchers and institutions were the most valuable aspects of the symposia, closely followed by updates on new advances in research fields other than their own. For example, prior to their participation in the program, less than 15 % of US respondents had collaborations with researchers in the MENA region. This number jumped to 63% following their attendance, showing a marked change in engagement with Arab counterparts. Additionally, given the multidisciplinary nature of the event, 72.9% of attendees indicated that their participation in the symposia led to new developments and ideas in their research. 


Last, building new collaborations between the United States and the Arab world continues to be of critical importance. While many see the current geopolitical context as a deterrent to work with the Arab world, we believe that it is now more imperative to strengthen relationships with this part of the world through science diplomacy, especially in light of the Covid-19 pandemic.
